Expectation1: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation1: A cruising aircraft simply requests the routine altimeter setting.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: An online candidate forum for their district is streaming now.
Story: The headset pressed against my ear as I scanned the radar, my eyes flicking to the clock. The candidate forum for my district was streaming live—this was my chance to hear their plans, to ask about the new zoning laws that would affect my neighborhood. But right now, Flight 482 was requesting the altimeter setting, a routine call, but one that demanded my full attention. I pressed the button, voice steady, “Flight 482, altimeter two niner niner two.” My phone buzzed with a reminder: “Forum live now—submit your question!” I felt the weight of civic duty, the urge to participate, to be more than a silent observer in my community. But the airspace was busy, and every second my focus wavered, lives were in my hands. I wanted to be a good citizen, to make my voice heard, but I was also the calm in the storm for pilots above. The demands pulled at me, each urgent in its own way, and I sat frozen, headset on, phone in hand, torn between the sky and the ground.
